one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: Courtyard
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Role: Hub, orientation point, pressure amplifier
Risk Level: Low
Always Accessible: YesYou emerge into a wide, open courtyard of cracked stone and fractured geometry. Above you, the sky is wrong. Clouds slide past in layers, some moving faster than others, some not moving at all. The air hums with a low vibration you feel in your teeth more than you hear.At irregular intervals, parts of the castle around you flicker. Towers fade to translucent outlines. Walls briefly show what lies beyond them, then snap back into place.Kethrys is not collapsing.It is slipping away.Make these clear within the first minute:
This space feels relatively stable
Other rooms are visible only when aligned
Exits are archways, not corridors
Some archways are solid. Others are hazy or incomplete
Point out which archways are currently in phase. Make it obvious that others are not.
In-phase archways look solid and reachable
Phased-out archways appear as: Faint outlines
Shimmering doorframes
Empty spaces where a passage should be Players immediately understand:
“We can’t go everywhere right now.”
No roll required.Reveal one detail every few minutes they remain here, or whenever they hesitate.After a short pause:
Gravity subtly shifts. Small debris slides uphill. After further delay:
The sound of distant stone grinding echoes, slightly out of sync.
After notable hesitation:
One visible archway flickers and phases out.
Another flickers into alignment elsewhere.
If they linger too long, advance the dungeon clock.The Courtyard supports:
Regrouping
Brief planning
Short rest attempts (at cost)
Waiting for alignment changes
Make it clear:
This space buys clarity, not safety
Nothing here stops the castle from moving
If a character is alone here during a shift:
Gravity lurches
Vision blurs
Suggested Check:
Dexterity or Constitution save DC 12On Failure:
Knocked prone, minor damage, or momentary disorientationUse the Courtyard to:
Show the dungeon clock advancing
Swap which rooms are accessible
Telegraph danger without combat
Reunite separated characters
This is where players feel the rules of Kethrys most clearly.Leaving the Courtyard always feels risky.Describe:
The momentary resistance of crossing thresholds
The sense of committing to a choice
The Courtyard shifting slightly once they leave
The castle notices movement.This scene never truly ends.It recurs throughout Act II as:
The regroup point
The reference frame
The reminder that time is passing
Although the Courtyard remains stable, no true exit from Kethrys is accessible during Act II.
Any archway resembling the original entrance is incomplete or misaligned Attempts to leave lead to: A short loop back into the Courtyard
A brief planar slip that returns them elsewhere inside Kethrys
A sensation of resistance, as if the castle is no longer aligned with the outside world Do not state this as a rule. Let players test it once if they try.The exit does not fully align until the Throne Room becomes accessible and the castle reaches a later stage of transit.If a player says:
“Can we just leave?”
Respond with description, not mechanics:
“The archway looks solid for a moment, then folds back in on itself.”
“You step forward and feel pressure, like walking into a strong wind.”
“The view beyond the archway is not the field you entered from.”
No roll required. No damage. No lecture.They learn:
“We are committed, whether we like it or not.”

headers.heading: SOLO RISK (IF ALONE DURING PHASE SHIFT)

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/Acts/Scenes/Courtyard.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: Grand Dining Hall
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Role: False refuge, time sink, atmospheric pressure
Risk Level: Low to Medium
Accessibility: Phases in and outYou step into a vast dining hall lined with long stone tables and high-backed chairs. The space is intact in a way much of the castle is not. Banners hang unmoving along the walls. Plates, goblets, and serving dishes sit where they were last placed.For a moment, everything feels still.Then a chair scrapes across the floor with no one touching it.
A goblet tips, falls, and shatters.
The sound echoes twice, slightly out of time.Make these clear early:
This room feels more stable than most
The air is quiet, heavy, and muted
No immediate threat is visible
Time feels slightly stretched here
This room invites the party to pause.The Dining Hall exists slightly out of sync with the rest of Kethrys.
Sounds lag or repeat
Movement feels slowed or oddly smooth
Planar echoes replay fragments of the past
Nothing here attacks on its own.The cost of this room is delay.Reveal one detail each time they hesitate or spend time here.After a short pause:
The smell of food briefly fills the air, then vanishes.
After further delay:
Ghostly figures flicker at the tables, mid-conversation, then disappear.
After notable hesitation:
Cutlery rattles. One table phases halfway into the floor.
The dungeon clock advances.
Make it clear: staying here feels safe, but it is not free.Players may:
Search for supplies or clues
Attempt a short rest
Observe planar echoes
Regroup and plan
Suggested Checks (Optional):
Investigation or Perception DC 12 to notice repeating echoes
Insight DC 12 to realize the room distorts time slightly
Success provides information, not advantage.Use the Solo Phase Risk Table.Dining Hall Result:
Disorientation from looping echoes.Effect:
Disadvantage on the next roll or loss of time.No combat. No major damage.When this room is about to phase out:
Conversations echo backward
Banners ripple as if pulled by unseen wind
The far end of the hall blurs
Give at least one warning before alignment breaks.Leaving feels reluctant, like pushing through thick air.When the party exits:
The room may remain visible briefly
Or fade immediately, depending on the dungeon clock
Either reinforces impermanence.The scene ends when:
The party leaves voluntarily
The room phases out
Pressure elsewhere pulls attention away
This room is never mandatory.

headers.heading: WHAT THE ROOM IS DOING (DM ONLY)
SOLO RISK (IF ALONE DURING PHASE SHIFT)

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/Acts/Scenes/Grand Dining Hall.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: Guard Barracks
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description: Role: Moral friction, social tension, imperfect allies Risk Level: Medium Accessibility: Phases in and outThe barracks are narrow and reinforced, with low stone ceilings and thick support beams. Weapon racks line the walls, many still holding rusted blades and cracked shields. Bedrolls lie where they were dropped long ago.This place feels used.A flicker of movement catches your eye. Someone is here, watching you from behind overturned bunks.Make these clear quickly: This room feels more sheltered than most It has been occupied recently The occupants are alert, frightened, and armed Violence here would be loud and costly A small group of scavengers has taken shelter here after entering Kethrys earlier. They know the castle is unstable. They want to leave. They also want what they came for.They are not villains. They are desperate.What they have: Minor supplies Partial knowledge of the castle’s shifts A lesser planar trinket they are unwilling to abandon What they do not have: A way out Trust in strangers Time to argue endlessly 1. Escort Them The party agrees to bring the scavengers along. Slows movement Complicates future phase shifts Creates later sacrifice or rescue moments 2. Ignore or Abandon Them The party leaves them behind. No immediate mechanical cost Clear narrative consequence later Scavengers may reappear or be referenced 3. Fight Them The party uses force. Costs time Makes noise Advances the dungeon clock No option is framed as correct.If discussion drags: A planar tremor shakes the room One exit begins to blur The dungeon clock advances Pressure resolves indecision.Use the Solo Phase Risk Table.Barracks Result: Isolation or confrontation.Effect: Threatening standoff Loss of equipment Minor damage Or dungeon clock advance No one is killed off-screen.Before this room phases out: Support beams creak Light bends around doorframes Sounds from elsewhere bleed in Give a warning. Then move on.Leaving feels cramped and rushed.If scavengers are with the party: They hesitate They argue They slow decisions If abandoned: The room feels emptier than it should Both outcomes matter later.The scene ends when: The party commits to a choice The room phases out Time pressure overrides conversation

headers.heading: SOLO RISK (IF ALONE DURING PHASE SHIFT)

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/Acts/Scenes/Guard Barracks.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: Keystone Chamber
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Role: Climax, decision point, point of no return
Accessibility: Phase 3 only
Tone: Finality, pressure, containment rather than victory(Read or paraphrase)Beyond the throne, the world narrows.You step into a chamber carved from a single sweep of stone, vast and impossibly precise. The walls curve inward, not to enclose you, but to focus you. Every surface is etched with planar sigils worn smooth by centuries of strain.At the center of the chamber floats the keystone.It hangs suspended in open air, a massive shard of rune-carved stone threaded through with pale light. The air around it ripples constantly, as though reality itself is being pulled tight and released in slow, painful breaths.The sound here is wrong.
Not loud.
Not silent.
A deep, constant pressure, like standing too close to something immense.This is not a place of power.It is a place of containment.Make these clear without explanation:
The keystone is holding something together
It is under enormous strain
Removing or damaging it will change everything immediately
There is no clean way to do this
This is the decision the entire dungeon has been moving toward.The Keystone Chamber is the last stable convergence point in Kethrys.
The keystone is actively resisting planar collapse
Every second here accelerates instability elsewhere
Once the keystone is disturbed, there is no pause button
This is the point of no return.Reveal one at a time as needed.
Hair and loose fabric drift toward the keystone
Cracks spiderweb across the floor, then seal again
The light within the keystone pulses irregularly
Distant stone grinding grows louder and closer
If hesitation continues, advance the dungeon clock.The first contact is unmistakable.Describe:
Intense resistance, like pushing against a storm
A surge of heat or cold
The sense of something not wanting to be removed, but not alive
No saving throw yet. Let the moment land.The instant the keystone is loosened, removed, or shattered:
The chamber lurches
The light fractures
The pressure snaps outward
Kethrys reacts.This triggers:
Act III
Pursuit
Structural collapse
The awakening of the planar warden
Do not delay. Momentum takes over.Once the keystone is dealt with:
The chamber becomes unstable
Remaining is no longer an option
Escape is urgent and dangerous
There is no time to examine the aftermath.This scene ends when:
The keystone is removed or destroyed
The castle begins active collapse
Act III pursuit begins immediately
Do not allow rest or reflection here.

headers.heading: WHAT THE CHAMBER IS DOING (DM ONLY)
OPTIONAL DETAILS IF THE PARTY HESITATES

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/Acts/Scenes/Keystone Chamber.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: Throne Room
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Role: Gate, escalation point, Act II culmination
Risk Level: Medium
Accessibility: Phases in late Act II
Restriction: Keystone Chamber inaccessible until ACT IIIThe Throne Room is vast and vertical, its ceiling lost in shadow and fractured arches. A raised dais dominates the far end, crowned by a massive stone throne carved with sigils worn smooth by time and planar erosion.Behind the throne, the air itself appears strained. Reality bends there, as though something immense presses against it from the other side.This place feels important.It also feels unfinished.Make these clear within moments:
This room is the symbolic heart of Kethrys
The planar pressure here is stronger than anywhere else so far
Something lies beyond the throne
It is not accessible yet
Players should understand they are early, not wrong.The Throne Room is a convergence point, not the keystone chamber itself.
It aligns intermittently as Kethrys advances through its final transit
The planar seam behind the throne is incomplete
Attempting to force passage now is dangerous and ineffective
This room exists to:
Signal that the end is coming
Deny premature access
Escalate tension cleanly into Act III
Until Phase 3:
The planar seam behind the throne does not fully align
Attempts to pass through result in resistance, distortion, or backlash
No roll can force access early
Describe failure through sensation, not mechanics:
Crushing pressure
Visual doubling
A sense of being pushed back into place
This is not a puzzle. It is a timing gate.Lingering here is actively uncomfortable.Escalate gently but firmly:
Planar pressure intensifies
The throne vibrates subtly
The dungeon clock advances
If they linger too long:
The room becomes unstable
Retreat becomes harder
You foreshadow pursuit
This room does not reward patience.Use the Solo Phase Risk Table.Throne Room Result:
Planar pressure surge.Effect:
Damage, forced retreat to the Courtyard, or dungeon clock advance.Never isolate a player here for long.Before Phase 3:
The seam behind the throne flickers but never opens
The sound of stone grinding grows louder
Light bends toward the throne, not away from it
At Phase 3:
The seam stabilizes
The air stills briefly
The path to the Keystone Chamber becomes clear
This moment should feel earned.Leaving feels like backing away from a storm front.Reinforce:
The sense of unfinished business
The knowledge they must return
The rising cost of delay
This scene ends when:
The party retreats to continue Act II
ACT III is reached and the Keystone Chamber aligns
Planar instability forces escalation
This room is the hinge between Act II and Act III.

headers.heading: WHAT THE ROOM IS DOING (DM ONLY)
SOLO RISK (IF ALONE DURING PHASE SHIFT)

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/Acts/Scenes/Throne Room.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: Training Hall
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Role: High-risk zone, consequence amplifier
Risk Level: High
Accessibility: Phases in and out
Design Note: This room is intentionally more dangerous than othersThe training hall opens into a wide, circular chamber scored with weapon marks and scorched stone. Racks of practice weapons line the walls, some cracked, some half-phased into the stone itself. Faded sigils are carved into the floor in overlapping patterns.As you step inside, the air tightens.For a split second, you see figures moving at the edges of your vision. Blades raised. Spells half-cast.Then they are gone.Make these clear quickly:
This room feels active, not abandoned
The air vibrates with stored motion
This is not a safe place to linger
Being alone here would be dangerous You do not need to say why. The room communicates it.The Training Hall is replaying fragments of past drills, duels, and spell exercises as planar echoes.These echoes:
Do not think
Do not pursue intelligently
React violently to movement and presence
They are not monsters. They are residual force.If the party enters together:
Echoes flicker but do not fully manifest
Movement triggers near misses
The danger is real but manageable
Suggested Check (Optional):
Dexterity or Acrobatics DC 12 to avoid incidental damage while moving quickly.Failure:
Minor damage or loss of footing.This room punishes hesitation, not teamwork.If a character is alone here during a phase shift, or enters alone:State: Planar PocketPast training bouts fully replay.Blades swing. Spells discharge. The room does not slow down for you.Solo Challenge:
Dexterity save DC 14On Failure (choose one):
Meaningful damage
Knocked prone and disoriented
Gain one level of exhaustion
A second failure escalates consequences.This is the clearest signal in Act II that splitting up has teeth.Every round or extended pause here risks escalation.Options:
Advance the dungeon clock
Increase echo intensity
Force a choice to move or take damage
Do not allow this room to become a puzzle.Before the Training Hall phases out:
The echoes speed up
Weapon impacts overlap
The sigils on the floor glow unevenly
If players ignore the warning, consequences follow.Leaving feels like stepping out of a strong current.Once exited:
The echoes fade abruptly
Silence feels heavy by contrast
The party understands this place was not meant to be safe
The scene ends when:
The party moves on quickly
The room phases out
The danger has made its point
This room does not need to be revisited.

headers.heading: WHAT THE ROOM IS DOING (DM ONLY)

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/Acts/Scenes/Training Hall.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: 0 Introduction
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
A level 4 planar dungeon one-shot for 4 to 6 charactersThe Last Anchor of Aethyra is a time-pressured planar dungeon crawl where the dungeon itself is the primary antagonist. An ancient planar ruin known as Kethrys is in the final stages of phasing out of the Material realm. The party has a narrow window to enter, retrieve or neutralize a final planar keystone, and escape before the structure completes its transit.This is not an exploration dungeon. It is a controlled extraction under escalating pressure.
The dungeon is actively leaving reality
Time pressure is visible and enforced
Interior geometry shifts instead of expanding
The primary threat does not wait at the end but pursues the party out of the dungeon
Players are not uncovering secrets. They are racing inevitability.The party is summoned by their long-time patron, Archwizard Thalos Aethyrian, a powerful planar scholar who has tracked Kethrys for years. He is clear and unsentimental.Kethrys cannot be stopped. Five of its six anchors are already gone. One remains inside.If Kethrys departs with that anchor intact, the resulting planar rupture will devastate the region for miles. If the anchor is removed or destroyed before the transit completes, the damage will still occur but will be localized to the castle’s exit point.The party is not being sent to prevent disaster. They are being sent to contain it.Every meaningful choice trades time for safety or speed for risk.
Aid others and fall behind
Press forward and leave consequences unresolved
Fight and lose precious moments
Escape cleanly or escape alive
There is no path that avoids loss entirely.
Act I: Forced entry into a phasing planar ruin
Act II: Shifting interiors, unstable navigation, and moral friction with stranded scavengers
Act III: Keystone extraction, activation of a planar warden, pursuit, and a final confrontation beyond the dungeon
The dungeon contains six meaningful spaces. Each exists to increase pressure or force choice. There is no filler.
Urgency without panic
Unstable reality
Imperfect victories
Motion that cannot be stopped, only shaped
Run this adventure lean. Exposition comes from action, not explanation.Success is defined by escape and impact, not conquest.Possible outcomes include:
The party escapes with the keystone but leaves lasting scars
Kethrys departs forever but something follows them out
The region is spared widespread devastation at a severe local cost
Thalos is proven correct, but not comforted
All outcomes are valid if the pressure led there honestly.This adventure assumes the DM is comfortable with:
Enforcing visible time pressure
Prioritizing environmental threats over combat volume
Allowing morally uncomfortable outcomes
Ending the session without a clean victory lap
If the table expects a traditional room-by-room dungeon crawl, this adventure will feel wrong. That is intentional.
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/Acts/0 Introduction.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: 1 Act I
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Purpose:
Establish urgency, demonstrate that Kethrys is unstable, and get the party inside quickly without analysis paralysis.Target Runtime:
20–30 minutes at the table.The party arrives in an open field beneath a fractured sky moments after being teleported by Thalos Aethyrian. In the distance, Kethrys flickers in and out of reality. Each phase shift carries it farther away.The air hums. Gravity feels unreliable. The structure is already leaving.This is the party’s only chance to enter.
The castle appears solid, then translucent, then absent
Sections of stone overlap incorrectly when it phases
Wind pulls toward the structure, then abruptly reverses
Sound echoes out of sequence
Do not explain the planar mechanics. Let the scene show instability.Get inside Kethrys before the entry point phases out.There is no safe approach. Hesitation has consequences.The entry point to Kethrys is unstable and only partially aligned.Offer 2–3 clear approaches, for example (with suggested DCs):
Rush the opening as it stabilizes briefly (DC: 12, Check: Athletics or Acrobatics)
Use magic or tools to anchor themselves (DC: 14, Check: Athletics, Survival, or relevant tool use)
Split-second timing and coordination (DC: 12, Check: Group Dexterity or Intelligence check)
On failure: Minor damage or separation for one round inside, then regroupAny plan can work. What matters is speed.If the party proposes:
A clever combination of abilities
A resource cost they willingly accept
A dramatic, decisive plan
You may allow automatic success and advance the dungeon clock instead.This reinforces the theme: success costs time.
DCs should reinforce urgency, not punish creativity
Failure should cost time or position, not block progress
DCs should be suggested defaults, not mandatory rails
Never require more than one roll per character in Act I
If you break any of these, pacing dies.Use this scale consistently:
DC 10: Straightforward, risky but obvious
DC 12: Coordinated effort, good timing
DC 14: Clever or magical solution
DC 16: Desperate or high-risk play
Avoid DCs above 16 here. The dungeon itself is the threat, not the doorway.Failure does not stop entry. It adds friction.Possible costs:
Minor damage
One piece of equipment dropped or damaged
Party briefly separated but reunited immediately inside
The dungeon clock advances one segment
Never block entry entirely.Once the party crosses the threshold:
Place the 6 visible tokens - the "dungeon clock" on the table Explain that certain actions will advance it
Do not explain all triggers yet
The players should understand one thing:
time is the enemyAct I ends the moment:
The party fully enters Kethrys
The entrance collapses or phases away behind them
From this point forward, retreat is no longer trivial.
Over-describing the castle’s history
Letting the party debate optimal entry for too long
Running this as a combat encounter
Explaining planar rules up front
If discussion stalls, advance the clock and shift the structure.You are not testing skill.
You are testing decisiveness.Kethrys does not wait.

headers.heading: VISUAL AND SENSORY CUES (USE 2–3, NOT ALL)

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/Acts/1 Act I.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: 2 Act II
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Purpose: Apply sustained pressure, teach phasing rules, and force at least one costly choice before the keystone becomes accessible.Target Runtime: 60–90 minutes.Kethrys is a castle phasing steadily out of the Material realm. Rooms align and misalign as planar layers slide past one another. The party navigates a hub-and-spoke layout anchored by the Courtyard. Timing determines access.The castle is not hostile. It is leaving.Kethrys contains six conceptual spaces: Courtyard of Arrival (always accessible)
Grand Dining Hall
Guard Barracks
Training Hall
Throne Room (keystone approach)
Keystone Chamber (Act III only) During Act II: Courtyard is always present Two rooms are initially accessible A third may align later All others are phased out, not erased Players identify rooms only after entering them.When the dungeon clock advances: One accessible room phases out One inaccessible room phases in Courtyard remains unchanged Phase shifts are telegraphed but not fully explained.If the party splits and a phase shift occurs: Isolated characters face solo risks using the table above Training Hall and Keystone Room are always high risk when solo Splitting up is allowed. It is never safe.Use this table only when a character is alone during a phase shift.Guidelines: One roll per solo scene No instant death Scene resolves in 5–10 minutes Rejoin on next phase shift or Courtyard alignment There is no explicit goal.Act II succeeds when players: Feel time pressure Make at least one non-optimal choice Reach alignment with the Throne Room Act II ends when: The party enters the Throne Room The dungeon clock reaches the Act III trigger Retreat becomes dangerous You are managing inevitability, not navigation.Kethrys proceeds whether the party is ready or not.
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/Acts/2 Act II.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: 3 Act III
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description: Role: Chase, escalation, release of pressure Tone: Urgent, violent, unstable Runtime: 30–45 minutes Trigger: Keystone removed or destroyedThe moment the keystone is disturbed, Kethrys stops slipping quietly.The castle lurches violently between planes. Walls grind. Floors tilt. The containment protocols fail. Something awakens.The Planar Warden begins moving toward the party immediately.This act is not about exploration. It is about escape under pursuit.The instant the keystone gives way, the chamber shudders.Stone screams against stone. Light fractures across the walls. Somewhere deep within Kethrys, something moves with purpose for the first time in centuries.A presence surges toward you.Not hunting. Not raging. Correcting.The castle lurches again, harder this time, phasing violently in and out of alignment.You have moments. The Planar Warden is bound to Kethrys It awakens when containment fails It does not speak It does not stop It will: Pursue relentlessly Ignore lesser obstacles Be delayed, not defeated, inside the castle Killing it inside Kethrys is not the goal.This is a narrative chase, not a tactical dungeon crawl.Run it as: A sequence of fast decisions One roll per character per major obstacle Failure costs time, position, or HP Advance the dungeon clock aggressively here.Present two clear options quickly.The path back through the Courtyard aligns briefly.Pros: Familiar route Fastest escape Cons: The Warden can follow Least cover during pursuit This is the clean escape.A secondary route reveals itself as the castle shudders. A narrow maintenance passage Collapsing Too small for the Warden to pass fully through Pros: Temporarily blocks pursuit Buys time Cons: Dangerous descent Scattered exit location outside The Warden will still emerge later This is the desperate escape.Use escalating descriptions: Floors tilting mid-stride Walls phasing into obstacles Gravity surging unpredictably When momentum slows: Advance the clock Bring the Warden closer Collapse something behind them Do not stall.Failure should: Separate the party briefly Inflict damage or exhaustion Cost equipment or positioning Never stop the chase entirely.The castle does not wait.Once the party clears either route: Kethrys phases violently behind them The exit snaps shut or tears free The Warden follows moments later, partially manifested This leads directly into the outside confrontation.Act III ends when: The party escapes the castle The Warden fully emerges outside The environment stabilizes enough for a final stand From here, initiative may finally be rolled.You are not adjudicating movement. You are maintaining pressure.If players stop moving, the castle moves for them.
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/Acts/3 Act III.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.title: PATRON Archwizard Thalos Aethyrian
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.description: Planar Scholar, Last Warden of AethyraRole: Patron, truth-holder, damage mitigator Alignment: Pragmatic Neutral Presence: Calm, exhausted, precise Vibe: A man who has already seen the cost of hesitation and refuses to repeat itThalos Aethyrian has been the party’s long-term patron. He is a respected archwizard whose reach extends beyond any single city or faction. His specialty is planar containment, not planar conquest.The party trusts him implicitly. When Thalos says something must be done, it is because every other option has already failed.He is powerful, but not omnipotent. What unsettles him is not danger, but inevitability.(These facts are delivered in writing, not spoken) The castle cannot be stopped. Its transit across the planes is already underway. No remaining spell, ritual, or force can arrest it. One final anchor still exists within it. There were once six planar anchors. Five have already been destroyed. The last remains as a keystone buried deep within the structure. Alone, it cannot hold the castle in place. If the castle departs with the anchor intact, the damage will be catastrophic. As the castle phases out, the anchor will tear free, ripping a wound between planes that will spread across the region for miles. Removing the anchor does not prevent destruction. It contains it. If the anchor is removed or destroyed before transit completes, the rupture will still occur, but it will collapse inward. The damage will be localized to the castle’s exit point instead of scarring the land for generations. If you are reading this, Kethrys has already begun its final transit. There is no method remaining to stop it. The structure you are approaching is a planar ruin once stabilized by six anchors. Five have already failed or been destroyed. The last remains in place as a keystone deep within Kethrys. Alone, it cannot hold the structure. If Kethrys completes its departure with the keystone intact, the anchor will tear free as it phases out. The resulting rupture between planes will spread outward for miles, scarring the Material realm beyond recovery. If the keystone is removed or destroyed before the transit completes, the rupture will still occur. It will collapse inward instead of outward. The damage will be confined to the castle’s exit point. Retrieve the keystone if you are able. Destroy it only if you must. Be warned that it is powerful, unstable, and may resist interference. Your survival matters. Nothing is gained if you are lost within Kethrys. Time is already against you. Thalos Aethyrian Planar Scholar Last Warden of AethyraThalos does not explain. He does not justify.He hands the party a sealed letter, already warm with residual magic, and says only: “You will not stop it. You will only decide how it leaves.” -- Wait a short beat like you are thinking about explaining personally then before the party can interrupt -- “Read this. There is no time.” How long the castle will remain accessible What guards the final anchor Whether anything inside understands what is happening Not because he is cruel. Because he does not know. Never raise his voice Never speculate aloud Never promise success Treat the party as capable adults, not heroes He is not sending them to win. He is sending them to limit the damage.DM Framing and OpeningThalos Aethyrian has been your patron for years. When he summons you personally, it is never for routine work.This time, he looks tired in a way you have never seen before.He does not sit you down. He does not explain the situation. He presses a sealed letter into your hands and says: “Read this on the way. There is no time to explain.” With a single spell, the world folds.Moments later, you are standing in an open field beneath a fractured sky. The air hums. Reality feels thin. In the distance, a ruined castle flickers in and out of existence, each phase carrying it farther from the world you know.The letter in your hand details what Thalos knows with certainty. The castle is leaving. One final anchor remains inside. If it is not removed, the damage will be widespread and irreversible.You cannot stop what is happening.You can only decide how bad it will be.

headers.heading: The spell completes before questions can be asked.

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/NPCs/PATRON Archwizard Thalos Aethyrian.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.title: Planar Warden
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.description: Role: Pursuer, final pressure, containment enforcer Type: Medium Construct (Planar) Alignment: Unaligned Mindset: Corrective, relentless, silentThe thing that emerges from Kethrys is not born of flesh or intent.Stone and sigil interlock around a hollow core of warped light. Its shape is humanoid only because that is the most efficient way to move through a world not meant for it. Cracks run through its body, sealing and reopening as it steps.It does not roar. It does not threaten.It moves toward the instability.Toward you.Armor Class: 15 (planar plating) Hit Points: 85 Speed: 30 ft.STR 16 (+3) DEX 12 (+1) CON 18 (+4) INT 6 (−2) WIS 12 (+1) CHA 6 (−2)Saving Throws: Con +6, Wis +3 Damage Resistances: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks Condition Immunities: charmed, frightened Senses: darkvision 60 ft., tremorsense 30 ft. Languages: understands Common and Primordial but does not speak Challenge: 4 (1,100 XP)Planar Anchor Core At the start of each of the Warden’s turns, it gains 5 temporary hit points as planar energy stabilizes it.Relentless Pursuit The Warden ignores difficult terrain and has advantage on checks or saves made to resist being slowed, restrained, or knocked prone.Containment Directive The Warden has advantage on attack rolls against creatures carrying or having recently handled the keystone.Multiattack The Warden makes two Slam attacks.Slam Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (1d10 + 3) bludgeoning damage.Planar Disruption (Recharge 5–6) The Warden releases a pulse of unstable energy in a 10-foot radius. Each creature in the area must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw On a failure: 10 (3d6) force damage and pushed 10 feet On a success: Half damage, no push This ability cracks the ground and distorts space.Phase Step (1/round) When the Warden is hit by an attack, it can partially phase, reducing the damage by 5 and shifting up to 10 feet without provoking opportunity attacks. It does not taunt It does not retreat It does not chase downed characters unnecessarily It focuses on containment, not slaughter Inside Kethrys: It cannot be killed cleanly Delays and terrain matter more than damage Outside Kethrys: It can be fought Victory is driving it off, destabilizing it, or surviving long enough Planar rifts open briefly each round Gravity shifts at initiative count 20 The ground cracks when the Warden uses Disruption These replace adding more enemies.The Warden is defeated when: Reduced to 0 HP Forced back into a planar rupture The keystone’s energy overloads it It loses alignment with the Material plane Do not require a kill unless the party insists.
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/NPCs/Planar Warden.md

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.title: The Scavengers
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.description: Role: Moral friction, imperfect mirrors, optional combat Disposition: Wary, desperate, pragmatic Group Size: 3–4 scavengersThese scavengers entered Kethrys earlier, chasing relics and planar salvage. They did not understand the castle was in its final transit until it was too late.They are not evil. They are not brave. They are trying to survive without walking away empty-handed.They have seen rooms vanish.They know time is running out. Defensive, not aggressive Weapons ready but not raised Will bargain, lie, or threaten before fighting Will flee if the fight turns against them If attacked, they fight dirty and fast. To escape Kethrys alive To keep at least one valuable item To avoid drawing attention They will not give up their prize easily, but they can be convinced.The scavengers respond to: Clear leadership Shared urgency Promises of escape Proof the party knows more than they do They shut down if: Threatened without leverage Mocked or dismissed Pressured while the castle shifts If negotiation drags, advance the dungeon clock.(Use only if things go wrong)Medium humanoid (any), unaligned Armor Class: 14 (leather, shield) Hit Points: 27 (5d8 + 5) Speed: 30 ft.STR 14 (+2) DEX 12 (+1) CON 12 (+1) INT 10 (+0) WIS 11 (+0) CHA 10 (+0)Skills: Athletics +4, Perception +2 Senses: passive Perception 12 Languages: Common Challenge: 1 (200 XP)Actions Multiattack. Two melee attacks. Shortsword. +4 to hit, 5 ft., 6 (1d6 + 2) piercing. Shield Bash (Recharge 5–6). Target must succeed on DC 12 Strength save or be knocked prone.Medium humanoid (any), unaligned Armor Class: 13 (leather) Hit Points: 18 (4d8) Speed: 30 ft.STR 11 (+0) DEX 14 (+2) CON 10 (+0) INT 10 (+0) WIS 11 (+0) CHA 10 (+0)Skills: Stealth +4, Acrobatics +4 Senses: passive Perception 12 Languages: Common Challenge: 1/2 (100 XP)Actions Dagger. +4 to hit, 5 ft. or 20/60 ft., 5 (1d4 + 2) piercing. Crossbow. +4 to hit, 80/320 ft., 6 (1d8 + 2) piercing.Bonus Action Disengage or Hide.If combat breaks out: Keep it short Keep it loud Advance the dungeon clock at least once The scavengers: Use cover Retreat if bloodied Do not fight to the death A prolonged fight here is a failure state for everyone.If the party kills them: Time is lost Noise echoes through Kethrys The castle reacts If the party spares or escorts them: Later complications Hard choices during Act III Narrative weight, not mechanical reward
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.sourcePath: One Shots/The Last Anchor of Aethyra/NPCs/The Scavengers.md

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
